node.title: Catharsis Songs
node.content: ["Welcome. A few weeks ago, I wrote about the release that songs like Taylor Swift\u2019s \u201cAll Too Well (Taylor\u2019s Version)\u201d provide. I asked for your catharsis songs, the tracks that help you process big emotions, and you delivered. We\u2019ve compiled the songs you sent into a Spotify playlist \u2014 check it out. The emails you sent accompanying your submissions were often cathartic themselves. Here\u2019s a sampling.", "\u201cLost my aunt in May and my mom in July,\u201d wrote Elaine Jones from Atlantic City, N.J. \u201cPatti LaBelle, live in New York, singing \u2018You Are My Friend\u2019 held my fragile tears of grief gently. Life as I knew it will never be the same.\u201d", "Kate Lauderdale from Annandale, Va., is finding release listening to \u201cbig anthem songs\u201d like Indigo Girls\u2019s \u201cLand of Canaan\u201d and \u201cPrince of Darkness\u201d on her way to work. Linda Watson in Madison, N.J., said that \u201cTogether Again\u201d by Janet Jackson \u201cmakes you want to dance, and a little dancing always makes me feel better!\u201d", "For Mark Miller-McLemore in Brentwood, Tenn., it\u2019s Neil Young\u2019s \u201cHarvest Moon\u201d that does it: \u201cThis song has such a steady beat and lovely shuffling, swing. It\u2019s an ode to long love, which we all need to sustain ourselves in tough times,\u201d he wrote.", "Led Zeppelin\u2019s \u201cRamble On,\u201d with the \u201cburst of the chorus after the build of the intro\u201d provides catharsis for Megan Schade in Brooklyn. She wrote, \u201cTrust me, leaves are falling all around (hear that leaf blower going all day during Zoom meetings?); I\u2019ve smelled the rain (as much as possible through an N95), felt the pain (years since I\u2019ve hugged family) and I wish like heck my life once again had the spontaneity so I too could take flight on a whim, with the autumn moon lighting my way.\u201d", "And Norah Blackaller from Downers Grove, Ill., wrote: \u201cMy catharsis song is Springsteen\u2019s \u2018The Promised Land.\u2019 The harmonica launch. The gutturals. The solos. And the lyrics! I vividly remember driving to the hospital in the days my father was dying, playing this song, singing, crying and then pulling myself together and heading to his room. It always makes me cry a little, and it reminds me of the joy of being alive.\u201d", "Have a listen to the playlist. If we missed your catharsis song, send it to us and we\u2019ll add it to the list.", "From \u201cYou Can Make Any Day the Best Day of the Year,\u201d by Lindsay Crouse.", "We\u2019re collecting your best of 2021. Send us your favorite things that you watched, read, listened to and otherwise did to pass the time this year and I\u2019ll include them in an upcoming newsletter. You can write us at athome@nytimes.com. Include your full name and location, if you please. We\u2019re At Home and Away. We\u2019ll read every letter sent. And of course you\u2019ll find more ideas for leading a full and cultured life \u2014 wherever you find yourself \u2014 below. I\u2019ll see you on Friday.", "Were you forwarded this newsletter? Times subscribers can sign up here to receive it twice a week. There\u2019s more to read, do and watch in our archive. Let us know what you think."]
